content.title: Moka Bros, for food both healthy and trendy

introduction.small: Facing the Xianyang park in Shanghai, Moka Bros is a trendy cafe where relaxation and health are the key words.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Moka Bros, for food both healthy and trendy

paragraphs.text:
Trendy Shanghai youth meet in this vast space where decoration switches from modern to retro. For brunch, lunch or a simple snack, Moka Bros' menu offers a large selection of dishes: sandwiches, salads, wraps, poke bowl… There, healthy food is no mere slogan, and the peaceful, cocoon-like atmosphere helps to enhance its enjoyment. Inside or on the large terrace, discover aspects of Venezuelan and Colombian cultures, related to the chef's two friends who originated the project. Daniel and Alex's bet was to put fresh and healthy food forward in a “fast casual” concept, hybrid between fast and healthy foods. Try the kale sandwich, with nuts, goat cheese, caramelised onions and raisins, or the Aloha poke bowl (tuna, seaweed, marinated ginger, green onion, macadamia nut and mango). A relaxing break in a colourful and tropical setting.

Moka Bros
108 Xiangyang North Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 3669 6080

www.mokabros.com

Menu: around 70 CNY

content.title: Capella Shanghai, luxury villas in the heart of Shanghai

introduction.small: With about 50 small luxury houses in the city centre, Capella Shanghai pays tribute to the French-Chinese heritage of the neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Capella Shanghai, luxury villas in the heart of Shanghai

paragraphs.text:
Lining up old school villas, Capella Shanghai looks more like a small neighbourhood than a hotel. These houses, in which traditional architecture and contemporary luxury mingle, are actually references to the shikumen, typical housing built by the French community in the 1930s. From 1849 to 1946, parts of Shanghai had actually been handed over to the French government.
Paying tribute to Shanghai's cultural heritage, the hotel created a Belle-Époque-style French-Chinese fusion with these sumptuous villas. Offering a minimum surface of 100 sqm, they are fully independent and offer a patio, a secret garden and a rooftop terrace. They are truly ideal for both romantic and family stays, as some shikumen offer three bedrooms. For a moment of relaxation after a long day wandering through the city, head to the spa, in which you may also order traditional Chinese skin care treatment. A haven of peace in the very heart of Shanghai.

Capella Shanghai
480 West Jianguo Road
Xuhui District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5466 9928

www.capellahotels.com/en/capella-shanghai ﻿

Rooms: from 3,043 CNY

content.title: Jeju Izakaya, Korean fusion in a small group

introduction.small: Developing a concept of close proximity with the cooks, Jeju Izakaya unveils a Korean cuisine with a bistronomic twist.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jeju Izakaya, Korean fusion in a small group

paragraphs.text:
Jeju Izakaya has all the traits of a gastronomical myth: an intimate setting that serves only eight, no phone nor website, only a WeChat (the Chinese application) or Facebook contact to reserve. It is however no mirage, for hidden in a discreet Shanghai house, this fusion Korean restaurant will encourage the night's eight patrons to take a seat by the counter overlooking the kitchen. The place drew direct inspiration from Japanese izakayas, those small and affordable bistros in which closeness is key. Chan and Tom, the two Korean chefs, will chat with you as they prepare dinner, which will take the form of a tasting menu. Dishes come and go before you, with octopus ramen à la Jeju – Korean volcanic island –, a new interpretation of tteok-bokkis (very popular street food rice cakes) as well as tofu with kimchi and hollandaise sauce… You will not forget this authentic experience anytime soon!

Jeju Izakaya
1095 Yu Yuan Lu
Changning Qu
Shanghai

www.facebook.com/pages/category/Art/JEJU-izakaya-1903709309941405/

Menu: around 350 CNY

content.title: Okura Garden Hotel, at the heart of the French Concession

introduction.small: Like all of Shanghai, the Okura Garden Hotel shows the traces of Europeans in China in the past. The hotel brings together Occidental and Oriental cultures in style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Okura Garden Hotel, at the heart of the French Concession

paragraphs.text:
Established in the former French Concession in the heart of Shanghai, this imposing building has now been converted into a luxury hotel. Steeped in history, the hotel will dazzle you as soon as you enter. Take the time to admire the beauty of the columns carved with bathers. The classically decorated rooms are spacious and full of light, while the suites are decorated in a Japanese style.

For a walk, you will be spoiled for choice, the hotel being close to a large shopping district. You can also relax in the large garden and patio or enjoy the wellness area with sauna and Jacuzzi.

The hotel has five restaurants and three bars. Be sure to dine at Baiyulan, which serves excellent Cantonese and Shanghai specialties, with a delicious cocktail at Yelaixiang Bar before or after!

Okura Garden Hotel
58 Mao Ming South Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6415 1111

www.gardenhotelshanghai.com

Rooms: from 1,150 CNY

content.title: The seven treasures of Qibao

introduction.small: The Old City of Qibao in Shanghai hides many splendours hidden around a bend in the cobblestone streets. The temples, traditional houses and handicrafts are treasures from history, enriched by legends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The seven treasures of Qibao

paragraphs.text:
You will only need to travel 18 kilometres to leave behind the tumult of the centre of Shanghai. Built more than 1000 years ago, the city of Qibao takes you back in time to revisit the history of old Shanghai.

Legend has it that Qibao—literally the ‘city of seven treasures'—was indeed surrounded by seven wonders: a golden lotus, a millennial tree, a large bell, a golden rooster, a Buddha, chopsticks and an axe of jade. If archaeologists have shown that the first four really existed, only the golden lotus and the big bell are still visible today.

The streets and two waterways that cross the ancient village are lined with traditional houses, temples, gardens and restaurants that serve the local specialty: braised pork with spices. The shops offer a wide range of handicrafts.

Qibao Old City
Minhang District
201101 Shanghai

www.goqibao.com

content.title: The Seagull on the Bund - rooms with a view

introduction.small: Just a ten-minutes walk from the port of Shanghai and the Museum of Contemporary Art, an ideal choice for travellers who want to enjoy the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Seagull on the Bund - rooms with a view

paragraphs.text:
Ideally placed on the Bund, Shanghai's colonial wharf along the Huangpu River, this grandiose hotel offers modern comfort in the European fashion of the 1970s. Once past the impressive dome in the lobby, you will find yourself in a hotel room with chic retro decor. It may even be river-facing. The view of the Bund and the futuristic skyscrapers of the financial district of Shanghai, Pudong Lujiazui, is spectacular, especially at night. The very friendly staff is fluent in English, and a classic, copious breakfast is included in the price. To reach Nanjing Road's shopping area, or any other destination, just take a taxi from the hotel. Internet access is complimentary.

The Seagull on the Bund
60 Huangpu Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6325 11500

www.theseagullonthebund-shanghai.com

Rooms: from 250 CNY

content.title: Lan Xin Canting - in a Shanghainese home

introduction.small: Gourmet happiness in this restaurant of savouries and sweets that make the taste buds sing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lan Xin Canting - in a Shanghainese home

paragraphs.text:
In the former French Concession (1849 - 1946) with its tree-lined streets, there are still a few old, picturesque buildings among the offices, luxury hotels and residential buildings. Hidden in a tiny alleyway, this canteen is well known for its sweet and savoury compositions. It has no English menu, but photos and whatever your neighbour is eating will help you decide. Braised pork with green peppers, and steamed clams with shallots and ginger are stunning. Perfectly mastering superlative Cantonese family cooking is a couple of a certain age, who are completely unflustered by the crowd constantly at their door. If the wait is often long, patience is rewarded with the inexpensive menu and rare delicacies. The subtlety of their dim sum is the most tangible proof.

Lan Xin Canting
130 Jinxian Road
French Concession Lu Wan Qu
Shanghai ‎

+86 (0)21 6253 3554

http://gastronomyblog.com/2013/09/25/lanxin-canting-shanghai/

Menu: around 60 CNY

content.title: Honour the god of commerce on East Nanjing Road

introduction.small: Whether you are looking for something in particular or just want to browse, go to China's largest shopping street, East Nanjing Road.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Honour the god of commerce on East Nanjing Road

paragraphs.text:
The reputation of Nanjing Road, especially its eastern part, in the historic centre of Shanghai, owes nothing to chance. Some stores that still exist today were built in the 19th century. They have helped make China's first commercial street a paradise for shoppers, especially as it has become largely pedestrianised since 1999. Locals and Chinese and foreign tourists throng to its stores, which are open from 10:00 am to 10:00 pm.

What is there to buy on East Nanjing Road? You will find everything! Sportswear, clothing, electronics, jewellery, cosmetics, toys, watches, glasses, and food, as well as shops specialising in local crafts, calligraphy, paintings, silks, and traditional medicine, etc. Its extension, West Nanjing Road, carries Western luxury brands. Though department stores accept international credit cards, make sure you can pay in cash at small businesses.

East Nanjing Road
Huangpu
Shanghai

content.title: Yufo Temple: the Buddhist temple of jade

introduction.small: In this very busy temple, crowds of faithful come daily to pray to two beautiful jade Buddhas, one meditating, the other serenely awaiting death.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yufo Temple: the Buddhist temple of jade

paragraphs.text:
The history of the temple begins with a long journey, that of a Burmese monk returning with two jade Buddha statues. In 1917, a temple was built to welcome them, and it remains one of the most active temples in Shanghai. About 100 monks of the Zen school live here. Very quickly, one is struck by the followers' devotion. In one of the five courtyards, neighbourhood workers come and bow, standing, slightly leaning, while wielding big sticks of incense.

In the Hall of Heavenly Kings awaits a laughing Buddha. And once past the first courtyard, under four rows of beautiful red lanterns (red being the colour of love and compassion in Buddhism) you will meet other meditating believers, this time sitting on large red poufs. On the first floor sits the first jade Buddha meditating in a red and golden niche. Sitting, he measures 1.9 metres. The altar in front of him holds the offerings: lotus flowers and fruit, graciously presented in pyramids.

In the next room, that of the ‘Ancestors', is the second jade Buddha. Lying on his side, his head is supported by his right hand as he serenely awaits death…

Yufo Temple
170, Anyuan Road
Jing'an
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6266 3668

www.yufotemple.com

content.title: Ultraviolet by Paul Pairet: astounding

introduction.small: A secret place where haute cuisine goes with music, perfume, and games.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ultraviolet by Paul Pairet: astounding

paragraphs.text:
The richest, most mysterious and most beautiful culinary address in Shanghai. After 15 years of looking for backers, French chef Paul Pairet has made his dream come true: a mad, unheard-of, avant-garde gastronomic experience. Once a month, ten people, who share a table, meet in a secret location. There is no telephone number or address.

Register online and the Ultraviolet team gives you a time and meeting spot from which they take you to an unknown address in a large black-lit room. Twenty-two dishes are presented to you in an extraordinary show. Each dish is accompanied by a specially created environment derived from video, music, painting, sculpture… In short, madness.

A film projecting the ebb and flow of ocean waves accompanies a fine fish dish,as a marine fragrance diffuses slowly into the room. Giuseppe Arcimbol do portraits and Picasso still-lifes combine with word games, music ranging from AC/DC to Ennio Morricone, and, of course, divine dishes.

www.uvbypp.cc

Menu: around 4,000 CNY

content.title: Epicure on 45: a breath-taking tour of world cuisine

introduction.small: The revolving restaurant at the Radisson Blu Hotel Shanghai New World takes you on a gastronomic merry-go-round of tandoori chicken, bird's nest, and Mongolian lamb.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Epicure on 45: a breath-taking tour of world cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Where to go out at night in Shanghai? Bring family or friends to the revolving restaurant at the Radisson Blu. Go up to the 45th floor, 208 metres high. If you suffer from vertigo, opt for a table in the dining room rather than those located right next to the large windows.

Do not worry, you can still enjoy a breath-taking view. Why not start with a delicious glass of Bordeaux? And for dinner, be ready to try world cuisine: Indian, Chinese, Japanese, Italian, French, Moroccan... even vegetarian! The menu offers delicious small pizzas, grilled lobster, Mongolian mutton ribs, tandoori chicken, bird's nest,and a multitude of other dishes, served by an attentive staff.

Epicure on 45
Radisson Blu Hotel New World
88 Nanjing Road West
Huangpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6359 9999

www.radissonblu.com/en/newworldhotel-shanghai/restaurants

Menu: around 800 CNY

content.title: Shanghai Propaganda Poster Art Centre: my dazibao is so beautiful!

introduction.small: Immerse yourself in the Mao years through a unique collection of posters from that time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shanghai Propaganda Poster Art Centre: my dazibao is so beautiful!

paragraphs.text:
Peiming Yang created this unofficial centre, located in the basement of a residential building. He had amassed a private collection of 5,000 propaganda posters covering the period from the founding of the PRC in 1949 to the end of the Cultural Revolution, when Deng Xiaoping put an end to propaganda. Sumptuous, colourful posters decorate the walls.

The commentary in English and French is often far from complimentary about Maoist China. Historians, art lovers, people who are nostalgic about the past, and anyone interested in China's recent history will love this. Don't miss the giftshop, which sells the dazibaos, both originals and reproductions, as well as ration cards and old copies of the Little Red Book.

Shanghai Propaganda Poster Art Centre
Room B-OC
President Apartment
868, Huashan Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6211 1845

www.shanghaipropagandaart.com

content.title: The Yongfoo Elite: alongside Karl Lagerfeld and Sharon Stone

introduction.small: Fashion designer Wang Xing Zheng has transformed the former British consulate into a refined oasis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Yongfoo Elite: alongside Karl Lagerfeld and Sharon Stone

paragraphs.text:
It took a few years before Shanghai could delve freely into nostalgia for the 1930s. If you want to join this trend, choose Yongfoo Elite. The former British Consulate in the old French concession was bought by fashion designer Wang Xing Zheng, who turned it into an Art Deco temple, decorated with contemporary furniture and bright colours.

You will not find any better place in Shanghai to enjoy a cocktail than in this magnolia-scented garden next to the goldfish pond. Like Karl Lagerfeld, Sharon Stone, and Jackie Chan, dine on delicious Shanghainese cuisine on one of the two verandas, where the gold-leaf walls are patterned with ideograms and foliage motifs. And, of course, the kindness and attentiveness of the staff meet your highest expectations.

Yongfoo Elite
200, Yongfu Road
Xuhui
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5466 2727

www.yongfooelite.com

Menu: around 580 CNY

content.title: Hakkasan: for duck with caviar

introduction.small: The headquarters for fashion models and Shanghainese bankers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hakkasan: for duck with caviar

paragraphs.text:
What goes around comes around. The first Hakkasan, dedicated to Cantonese cuisine, was born in London. After opening 11 restaurants around the planet, the first Hakkasan finally opened in China. And in just two years, it has won a Michelin star.

This chic venue is the place to eat, to see and to be seen. Models and bankers are among the regulars. In a black spot-lit decor, with rice paper partitions, eat chicken with jasmine tea and mustard seed sauce, sautéed Angus beef sirloin with Merlot sauce, and crispy duck with caviar. Hakkasan also offers delicious dim sum.

Hakkasan
5th floor
18, Zhongshan East First Road
Huangpu District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6321 5888

www.hakkasan.com

Menu: around 600 CNY

content.title: Bar Rouge: as red as the Chinese flag

introduction.small: The most popular bar in the Bund is filled with the city's beautiful people.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bar Rouge: as red as the Chinese flag

paragraphs.text:
In keeping with its name, red dominates Bar Rouge. Red-leather banquette seating lines the inner room. The lighting is red. Photos of red-lipped models adorn the walls. A red dragon sits on the reception desk, and the red Chinese Communist flag flies on the terrace! Bar Rouge is the headquarters of Shanghai nightlife, mingling local gilded youth and expatriates.

Midnight dancing with the wind in your hair on the terrace looking out at the Oriental Pearl Tower will make your head spin. DJ Miss Elise plays groove; there are also hip-hop evenings. From here, you can closely admire the beautiful Bund buildings that date from the Roaring Twenties. By fusing two cultures, the Franco-Chinese management have made Bar Rouge a hotspot.

Le Bar Rouge
18, Zhongshan East First Road
Huangpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6339 1199

www.bar-rouge-shanghai.com

Admission with one free drink: around 200 CNY

content.title: The Oriental Pearl Tower: ascending to the sky

introduction.small: Shanghai gave itself a giant bilboquet-shaped tower at the beginning of a new era for the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Oriental Pearl Tower: ascending to the sky

paragraphs.text:
The Shanghainese are very proud of the Oriental Pearl Tower because it signalled their city's renaissance. Completed in 1994 and measuring 468 metres in height, the tower set the course for the Pudong business district on the banks of the Huangpu Jiang river.

Since then, a forest of skyscrapers has sprouted up. Legend has it that the Oriental Pearl Tower was inspired by a Tang dynasty poem, and that its three spheres of silver and pink represent pearls, while the river at its feet symbolises jade. Climb the third sphere up to 351 metres, and enjoy a unique view of the Bund. At the top, there is a TV antenna. And for lunch or dinner, go down to the rotating panoramic restaurant in the second sphere. At 263 metres, the view remains wonderful, especially in spots where the floor is made out of glass. Back on the ground floor, admire the pink of the tower, magnified by the glare of the sun.

Oriental Pearl Tower
1, Century Avenue
Pudong
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5879 1888

www.orientalpearltower.com

content.title: The Bund: the blazing sun hits the quayand the beach

introduction.small: The Bund whose quay the Shanghainese named Wai Tan, ‘path of foreigners', is a favourite place for going out, especially in the evening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bund: the blazing sun hits the quayand the beach

paragraphs.text:
No, the Bund has no link with Germany, despite its German-sounding name. It comes from a Persian word, chosen by the British, which means ‘dock'. This quay runs past almost a kilometre of majestic Art Deco buildings constructed at the turn of the 20th century by banks and foreign companies that were here to build China's version of Wall Street. The quay has been raised since, so that the Shanghainese and tourists can enjoy the view of bulk carriers and barges going up the Huangpu. In the background stand the gigantic skyscrapers of Pudong, which dwarf the Bund buildings.

Join the locals who like to come hang out here at dusk, especially at weekends, when the sun falls on the Pudong, bathing the stone and marble palaces in a golden glow. And if you go south of the quay, you can admire the spectacle with your feet dangling in the water, or while lying on a sandy beach that was constructed in 2013.

The Bund
Zhongshan East First Road
Huangpu
Shanghai

content.title: Wanshang Huaniao Market: perfect acoustics for cricket melodies

introduction.small: In this incredible market, the price of a boxer or musician cricket can go up to a thousand dollars a piece.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Wanshang Huaniao Market: perfect acoustics for cricket melodies

paragraphs.text:
Here is one of the last typical markets of Shanghai, where a crowd of mynah birds, each in its cage, welcomes you with nihao, which means ‘hello' in Mandarin. The parrots on their perch mimic them. Imagine a place that brings together squealing chinchillas, hundreds of croaking frogs, and hundreds of cicadas enclosed in wicker boxes chirping like they do in the South of France in summer. No scorpions, as in Canton, but there are tarantulas. Iguanas, pigeons, and puppies complete this Noah's ark.

You will then discover the star of the show, the cricket, which the Shanghainese believe brings good luck. At home, the Chinese love to be lulled to sleep by its melody. The market has a special room with very good acoustics so you can listen to a cricket before buying it!

Some species are sold for more than $1,000 a piece. Among them are fighting insects that have been trained by men using chopsticks while sitting on small stools in the open market.

Wanshang Huaniao Market
417 Xizang South Road,
Huangpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6336 3530

content.title: The high life at the Park Hyatt Shanghai

introduction.small: Sleep, dine, and swim in one of the tallest hotels in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The high life at the Park Hyatt Shanghai

paragraphs.text:
The Jin Tao is the building with the gigantic corkscrew-shaped tower on its roof that fascinated you as your plane was landing in Shanghai.

It is home to Shanghai's world financial centre and above it, from the 79th to the 93rd floors, the Park Hyatt, which was the tallest hotel in the world for a long time. The elevator in the private foyer on the ground floor whisks you up to the reception in record time. The Park Hyatt has taken maximum advantage of its stunning location. Its stylish rooms, with black lacquered doors and sleek furnishings in beige and brown, have huge windows. Ditto for many of the bathrooms, in which the shower is placed near windows, giving you the impression of taking a shower in the sky.

The infinity pool on the 88th floor will bring you similar joy. And for maximum relaxation, a tai chi master awaits you in the interior garden, high up in the air.

Park Hyatt Shanghai
100, Century Avenue
Pudong
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6888 1234

shanghai.park.hyatt.com/en/hotel/home.html

Rooms: from 1,581 CNY

content.title: The Nest Shanghai: a cocktail of vodka, oysters, and music

introduction.small: A nest for night owls in the Bund.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Nest Shanghai: a cocktail of vodka, oysters, and music

paragraphs.text:
Hidden behind the Rockbund Art Museum, this place was built on vodka. Vodka is not only used in creating excellent cocktails, but it's even in dishes like fish and chips!

Opened in autumn 2014, the Nest has quickly established itself as the Bund's seafood and oyster bar. This neighbourhood restaurant is trendy yet casual and unpretentious. If you prefer wagyu beef, Iberian ham, and great cheese platters, this cosy nest will suit you as well.

The airy space revolves around the bar, topped by a spine-like light sculpture. People don't just come to the Nest to eat, but to dance to good music, too. And there are two balconies for smokers. Book ahead.

The Nest Shanghai
6th floor
130, Beijing East Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6308 7669

Menu: around 500 CNY

content.title: The Waterhouse at South Bund China: shabby chic

introduction.small: A beautifully dilapidated concrete hotel south of the Bund, along the river.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Waterhouse at South Bund China: shabby chic

paragraphs.text:
A hotel that calls its rooms ‘Copula' deserves attention. Especially since the Waterhouse opts for shabby-chic decor. It is housed in an old warehouse formerly occupied by the Japanese, whose concrete and steel facade has crumbled over time. The front desk seems a little crushed in the vast emptiness of what was once the local delivery hall.

The deteriorating walls, stabilised but exposed, affirm the aesthetic. But rest assured about the rooms! Rather than raze the existing structure a very popular phenomenon in Shanghai the architects preferred to build on its industrial heritage by putting in white and blonde wood walls, giving each room the feel of a Scandinavian loft. The all-white patio will also seduce you, as will an enormous terrace in a minimalist style, offering a beautiful view of the river, and beyond, to Pudong and the Oriental Pearl Tower. And be sure to have the Waterhouse breakfast, considered one of the most copious in the city.

Waterhouse At South Bund China Hotel
Maojiayan Road No 1-3
Zhongshan Road South
Huangpu District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6080 2988

www.waterhouseshanghai.com

Rooms: from 880 CNY

content.title: Shanghai Circus World: multimedia acrobats

introduction.small: This is an amazing show, featuring a fire-eater in his ‘hamster' cage and bikers in large stainless steel balls.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shanghai Circus World: multimedia acrobats

paragraphs.text:
The Chinese love circuses and circus performers have very good reputations. ‘ERA-Intersection of Time' at the Shanghai Circus is excellent. It draws on ancient traditions to create a magical odyssey of multimedia, high-tech, and light and sound effects.

Giant screens boost the acrobatic prowess in the ring. The refined play of light accentuates the dreamlike nature of certain acts, such as the aerial acrobatics of a couple who tell a romantic story with total grace, conveying to us the essence of love through their art. Later, a juggler enters the ring on a life-sized gondola, perched on a rola bola. Fire-eaters and contortionists move through the air in three small cages, resembling those of hamsters, clinging to a large 15-metre wheel set in motion by an acrobat.

For the finale: eight bikers riding at full speed enclosed in a stainless steel ball.

Shanghai Circus World
2266, Gonghexin Road
Zhabei Qu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5665 6622

www.shcircusworld.com

content.title: Mandarin Oriental Pudong: swim with works of art

introduction.small: As if the refinement of its furnishings and exquisite courtesy of it staff were not enough to make its guests perfectly happy, the Mandarin also has the aspirations of a museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mandarin Oriental Pudong: swim with works of art

paragraphs.text:
Four thousand works of art are scattered throughout the hotel right up to the edge of the wonderful indoor pool, lined with palm trees, where you can dive in under the gaze of a minimalist marble bird. The pool is open around the clock. The Mandarin dares to be extravagant. The presidential suite, with two private gardens, takes up an entire floor of around 790 square metres.

With walls of glass, most rooms have spectacular views of the Pudong skyline, the Huangpu River, and the Bund. In the morning, simply press the button next to the bed to open the curtains and blinds, and enjoy the view. But perhaps you will just want to slumber in the Mandarin's extra high beds, which are so conducive to an excellent sleep. To help you feel at home, the exquisitely courteous and very attentive staff is at your disposal.

Mandarin Oriental Pudong
111 Pudong South Road
Pudong
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 2082 9888

www.mandarinoriental.com.tr/shanghai

Rooms: from 1,400 CNY

content.title: A walk in the old French concession

introduction.small: This area, which has transformed into a graceful fusion of French and Chinese culture, has become a favourite of Shanghai's chic crowd.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A walk in the old French concession

paragraphs.text:
The former French concession, about six kilometres long and stretching out on both sides of Huaihai Street, has become the fashionable place in town.

Discover the many Art Deco jewels in this neighbourhood of opulent residences, built by the West in the 19th and early 20th centuries, now converted into hotels and luxury shops. Only the Nanjing district in the north rivals the former concession in luxury, but you may find that the former is more ostentatious. Take the time to lose yourself in quiet havens lined with plane trees, like Café Petanque, with its rows of tables on the patio, or Rouge Baiser Elise, where people come to buy French linen and tableware.

A little further in Tian Zi Fang, unpretentious brick houses have been converted into small shops and eateries, frequented by a mix of young Shanghainese executives and a cosmopolitan crowd.

Shanghai French Concession
86, Wulumuqi Middle Road
Xujui
Shanghai

+86 21 5403 2582

content.title: The PuLi Hotel and Spa, and infinity bar

introduction.small: Vast common areas, which include a 32-metre-long bar, do not preclude intimate salons.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The PuLi Hotel and Spa, and infinity bar

paragraphs.text:
Travellers staying at PuLi will be hard-pressed to find faults: you will feel so good you may never want to leave. Located in a business district on the edge of the former French concession with its charming, trendy neighbourhoods, the hotel is close to Jing'an Temple. In fact, the Jing'an Temple Park seems to almost emerge through the bay windows in the huge lobby.

Despite its vast proportions, which include a 32-metre-long bar, there is still a feeling of intimacy. The lounges are decorated with a subtle blend of refined design and typically Chinese vases and prints. In the rooms, lacquer, wood, and bricks harmonise beautifully. And, though luxurious, PuLi is simple and warm in its hospitality, thanks to the friendliness and courtesy of the concierge and staff.

PuLi Hotel and Spa
1, Changde Road
Jing'an
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 3203 9999

www.thepuli.com

Rooms: from 1,928 CNY

content.title: Share your rice porridge with a tai chi master

introduction.small: Let us take you on three tasting tours through the streets of Shanghai.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Share your rice porridge with a tai chi master

paragraphs.text:
Here's a great idea. Shanghai has a very good culinary reputation. UnTour agency invites you on three different tours of Shanghainese cuisine: one dedicated to breakfasts, a second to dumplings, and finally a gourmet discovery of the night markets.

You will eat breakfast in shops alongside tai chi masters and people doing calligraphy. You can taste steaming rice noodles, oily doughnuts called doujiang youchao, and the famous Chinese cabbage, cai, stir fried in a wok with all sorts of condiments. And also try zhou, rice porridge served in the morning, enlivened with fermented soy cheese or dried fish. The dumpling tour ends with your learning how to make them yourself under the watchful eye of a local cook. Discover all the different ingredients that go into dumplings and try classic soup dumplings or xiaolongbao. In the evening, eat fresh shellfish, a wide selection of wok fried vegetables, spicy kebabs, and ethnic cuisines, like that of Muslim minorities. Enjoy your meal!

UnTour Shangai Food Tour
51 Tianping Lu
Bldg 27, 1/F
Shanghai

+86 (0)186 1650 4269

www.untourshanghai.com

content.title: Naked Stables Private Reserve, luxurious ecology

introduction.small: A 2 and 1/2-hour drive from Shanghai, this ecological paradise is a retreat balanced between advanced technology and artisanal craftsmanship.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Naked Stables Private Reserve, luxurious ecology

paragraphs.text:
Since the 1900s, Westerners in Shanghai have gone on holiday in the mountainous Moganshan area to escape the summer heat. The Naked Stables Private Reserve was inspired by these escapes to create an ecological paradise of 30 hectares sequestered among tea plantations and pine trees. The Naked Stables uses solar heating, composts its food scraps, and collects rainwater. But none of that involves you directly. You will stay in rooms with the latest technology, whose design is modelled on African huts.

Barbecue or relax in a Jacuzzi on your beautiful, sizeable terrace. And a large outdoor living room can accommodate family dinners in this idyllic landscape. Activities include swimming, horseback riding, hiking, and cycling on paths lined with bamboo. In the evenings, have dinner at the delicious and inventive organic restaurant, and take advantage of cultural events and craft workshops. In short, here, you are in a haven of luxury and sustainability.

Naked Stables Private Reserve
62 Gao'an Road
Xuhui Qu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 3401 2288

www.nakedretreats.cn/naked-stables-private-reserve/

Rooms: from 3,800 CNY

content.title: Longhua Temple: 108 bell strokes in a haven of peace

introduction.small: One of the most prominent Buddhist sites in Shanghai, this temple will offer you all the serenity you need.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Longhua Temple: 108 bell strokes in a haven of peace

paragraphs.text:
No doubt its situation in an outlying area, rich in parks and gardens, influences the atmosphere of the temple, whose calmness and serenity delight guests upon entry. The largest place of Buddhist worship in Shanghai has five pavilions. The principal pavilion, called the Treasury, is home to Buddhist effigies. Its tower features a collection of gongs and a bronze bell weighing six tonnes. If you are in Shanghai on the eve of Chinese New Year, go to the pavilion.

You will see the faithful hit the bell 108 times to scare away evil spirits from harming the new year. The third pavilion, the Thousand Luohan, will not fail to surprise you with its 500 golden statuettes. They represent the Arhat saints who have attained wisdom…

Longhua Temple
2853, Longhua Road
Xuhui District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6456 6085

content.title: LWH Gallery:contemporary art from Buddha's point of view

introduction.small: Artists from all over Asia meet in feverish Shanghai to exhibit works inspired by Buddhism.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LWH Gallery:contemporary art from Buddha's point of view

paragraphs.text:
Enter this charming place through pink-framed black wooden doors. You are lost in the maze of alleys in Moganshan Toad near the Suzhou River. Its owner, Hee Lee Woon, a passionate Singaporean, is wonderfully hospitable. Convinced he was a Buddhist monk in a previous life, Hee has designed his gallery to exhibit contemporary artists from all over Asia who have been inspired by the encounter of Buddhism and modern life.

Cosmopolitan and influenced by the cultures and religions of the many countries he has lived in, Hee also seeks to show how Asia's current upheavals stimulate Asian artists. Shanghai, with its extraordinary metamorphosis and its commitment to its customs, seemed the ideal city in which to open his gallery. Hee will also explain his support for artists who have been held back by families hostile to contemporary art.

LWH Gallery
Office 102
Building 14
50, Moganshan Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)187 0171 7975

lwhgallery.com

content.title: Jumeirah Himalaya Hotel Shanghai: extravagance, delicacy, and a museum

introduction.small: Right in the business district of Pudong, the very good feng shui of the 393-room Jumeirah goes hand in hand with the outrageousness of the lobby and roof.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jumeirah Himalaya Hotel Shanghai: extravagance, delicacy, and a museum

paragraphs.text:
The facade of the ground floor is draped in a mesh that evokes ideograms, flowing into a Gaudian Baroque style. Enter! A huge luminescent lobby, 16 metres high, welcomes you! Inspired by a piece of jade, it is adorned with a graceful gazebo in the middle. The mini-design version of a Buddhist temple roof sits atop three-metre-high walls. There are art objects and works of art everywhere.

The reception gives you an iPod audio guide that tells you everything about this private museum! The excess extends to the top floor, which has a roof terrace of 5,000 square metres. The auspicious feng shui of your very spacious room in sober wenge design is calming. The wonderful bedding and the perfect soundproofing create great serenity, as does the impeccable service.

As soon as you finish exercising in the gym, open around the clock, the staff is on hand with a towel. In front of the elevator, you are about to push the button to call it when a very discreet bellboy beats you to it. An absolute dream!

Jumeirah Himalaya Hotel Shanghai
1108 Meihua Road
Shiji Gongyuan
Pudong Sinqu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 3858 0888

www.jumeirah.com

Rooms: from 1,191 CNY

content.title: URBN Hotel Shanghai: the art of salvaging

introduction.small: The 26-room URBN offers a thousand wonders and, even, carbon credits.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: URBN Hotel Shanghai: the art of salvaging

paragraphs.text:
The vegetal wall on the concrete facade sets the hotel's ecological design tone. The architect salvaged and recycled the most luxurious, elegant mahogany from the surrounding French residences.

In the extremely refined lobby and rooms the mahogany is an enchanting motif. The whimsical wall of suitcases behind the reception counter harmonises with the rest of the lobby. The salvaged beige brick walls of the corridors confirm that ecology and luxury can be synonymous.

The hotel also allows guests to buy carbon credits to offset their flights. But first, Chinese cooking and Mandarin classes await, followed by healing acupuncture sessions.

URBN Hotel Shanghai
183 Jiao Zhou Lu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5153 4600

www.urbnhotels.com/en

Rooms: from 1,243 CNY

content.title: Nanshi: Shanghai's old city and the antidote to Pudong

introduction.small: The bustling charm of the refurbished heart of Shanghai!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nanshi: Shanghai's old city and the antidote to Pudong

paragraphs.text:
The Shanghainese have belatedly realised the value of their old city, Nanshi, located just below the Bund. They have rebuilt certain islands in the Ming style, and beautiful houses with curved roofs now seem larger than life.

There are manywelcoming shops and cafés. In addition to these vestiges of millennial China, there are more recent buildings dating from the last century, known as shikumen, which have also been restored. The lintel stone that surmount the entrances to these houses symbolises the meeting of European and Chinese styles.

To find peace in this lively neighbourhood, take refuge in Yu Garden or the Shanghai Temple of the Town God. And discover some of the most authentic places of worship in Shanghai: the Fuyou Lu Qingzhen Si Mosque; the Temple of Confucius, with its fragrant magnolia garden; or the Baiyun Temple, with its 8,000 Taoist scriptures.

Nanshi
Huangpu District
Shanghai

content.title: Ye Lixiali: an Uighur halal experience

introduction.small: One of the best lamb dishes in Shanghai is served with homemade yogurt, and accompanied by belly dancers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ye Lixiali: an Uighur halal experience

paragraphs.text:
Though Shanghai is better at integrating its Muslim minorities than you know, the fact remains that Ye Lixiali is not on the list of restaurants recommended by the hotel concierge. And, therefore, you will find few tourists in this halal restaurant, specialising in the cuisine of the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region. Do not be intimidated by the huge door: enter and receive a warm welcome.

The dishes are reminiscent of those of Turkey and the Middle East. Skewers of lamb are served with homemade yoghurt-based sauce. But Ye Lixiali offers many other lamb and mutton dishes, like delicious kidneys, which will appeal to the intrepid. The charm also lies in its private salons, where weddings and parties with belly dancers are regularly celebrated.

Ye Lixiali
Jinzhong Mansion
680, Zhaojiabang Road
Xuhui
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6466 8388

www.yelixiali.com

Menu: around 70 CNY

content.title: Chinese Printed Blue Nankeen Exhibition Hall: life through blue coloured glasses

introduction.small: For a long time, no one from Nanjing to Shanghai knew where to find blue cotton. Fortunately, those days are over.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chinese Printed Blue Nankeen Exhibition Hall: life through blue coloured glasses

paragraphs.text:
Lost in a maze of alleys in a working class neighbourhood in the former French concession, there is a place that sells handcrafted items in a beautiful raw cotton fabric in Nanjing blue.

The traditional method of manufacture, which dates back more than 300 years, is to first cut out the oiled, stencilled patterns which are then affixed to the fabric. A soybean paste is applied to the fabric, which is then immersed in a blue dye obtained from indigo leaves. After completion of the dyeing, the fabric is allowed to dry before the soybean paste is removed with a knife revealing a blue and white pattern.

Here, you will find hammocks, umbrellas, slippers, toys, and tablecloths in the most varied patterns. In short, very tasteful gifts to bring back from your trip to Shanghai.

Chinese Printed Blue Nankeen Exhibition Hall
No 24, Lane 637
Changle Road
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5403 7947

content.title: The Power Station of Art electrifies contemporary art

introduction.small: The exhibitions and architecture of the Power Station of Art attract Shanghainese with high expectations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Power Station of Art electrifies contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
Its tall chimney of 165 metres beckons from afar. Like the Tate Modern in London, the Power Station of Art next to the Huangpu River is a former power station. Before becoming the largest contemporary art centre in Shanghai, it was transformed into the Pavilion of the Future of the World for Expo 2010. Since then, it hosts the city's contemporary art biennial.

The Power Station of Art does not have a permanent collection. Instead, it curates top flight temporary exhibitions or displays touring exhibitions from major museums around the world. A gigantic surprise awaits you : 31,000 square metres spread over seven floors. Be sure you go to the top for a view of the former World Expo site.

Power Station of Art
678 Miaojiang Road
Huangpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 3110 8550

http://www.powerstationofart.com/en/

content.title: Zhujiajiao: the most beautiful bridges in China's Venice

introduction.small: Forty kilometres southwest of Shanghai, 36 precious bridges span the canals of a water-filled city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zhujiajiao: the most beautiful bridges in China's Venice

paragraphs.text:
Weeping willows on the banks of the canal will transport you far from the skyscrapers of Pudong and back to the Qing and Ming dynasties, during the golden age of Zhujiajiao, a city built in the 17th century.

Stay away from the most prestigious area, and focus your attention on the canal area, called the ‘little Venice of Shanghai'. Sampans take the place of gondolas rowed by ‘gondoliers' wearing cone-shaped straw hats. Thirty-six bridges made of wood, brick, and stone span canals that have been called ‘the streets of a thousand small shops' since the Qing dynasty.

The most famous bridge, the Fansheng Quiao, is made of stone, and has five arches guarded by eight lions at the top. But perhaps you might prefer the beautiful Lang Quiao veranda bridge, all in wood with a grey tile roof. Zhujiajiaois evidence of another miracle: despite the many films that have been shot in this city, its people have kept an authentic lifestyle.

Zhujiajiaozhen
Qingpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5924 0077

www.zhujiajiao.com

content.title: Sharks and fluorescent jellyfish, above your head

introduction.small: At the Shanghai Ocean Aquarium, the longest underwater tunnel in the world takes you on a tour of tropical and polar seas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sharks and fluorescent jellyfish, above your head

paragraphs.text:
Welcome to the largest aquarium in Asia, a 13,000 square-metre paradise for children. Thousands of animals can be observed here, including dozens of rare species from seemingly deep down in the sea. The aquarium is built on a centre piece, the longest underwater tunnel in the world, allowing you to observe the animals in a 270-degree panorama.

For your enjoyment, there are sharks, manta rays, and sea lions that swim above your head in a beautiful ballet. Microcosms were recreated in the aquarium as well as in the nine adjacent galleries. The journey begins in China and continues on to the Amazon, Australia, Africa, and the tropical forests of Southeast Asia. It ends with the polar world and its colony of 20 penguins, and ocean abysses. Among the rarest of residents are a giant salamander, Japanese spider crabs, fluorescent jellyfish, and shark eggs at different stages of gestation.

By way of goodbye, small doctor fish, or Garra rufa, will clean your hands if you plunge them into any of the aquariums provided.

Shanghai Ocean Aquarium
1388 Lujiazui Ring Road
Pudong
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 5877 9988

www.sh-soa.com

content.title: The Yifu Theatre: feudal, bourgeois, and dazzling

introduction.small: And if your heart should beat for an opera in archaic Mandarin with subtitles in Shanghainese dialect, perhaps with someone to explain it all in English? This is your place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Yifu Theatre: feudal, bourgeois, and dazzling

paragraphs.text:
On the facade, a huge multi-coloured mask signals the entrance to the room, which holds 350 performances a year. Built in 1925, it specialises in the dissemination of Jingji (‘Beijing Opera').

But let's be honest: a show spoken and sung in archaic Mandarin with Shanghainese dialect subtitles does not appeal to everyone. And yet, and yet… Try to attend at least one performance. The lavish sets and costumes dazzle you like the very pronounced makeup. The actors' gestures respond to very specific codes, and their acrobatics are accompanied by an impressive and forceful beating of drums and cymbals. The Jingji appeared in the late 18th century and nearly vanished during the Cultural Revolution because the Red Guards saw it as feudal and bourgeois. It now enjoys renewed interest.

Tip: make friends with an English-speaking Chinese spectator who will explain the show to you. Or find out about theatres nearby that put on Jingjie excerpts!

Yifu Theatre
701, Fuzhou Lu
People's Square
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6351 4668

www.tianchan.com

content.title: Jing'an Temple: a gangster abbot protected by Russian bodyguards

introduction.small: The Temple of Peace and Tranquillity has not always been true to its name!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jing'an Temple: a gangster abbot protected by Russian bodyguards

paragraphs.text:
Its cascade of golden roofs is visible from afar and its gleaming pagoda is reflected in neighbouring skyscrapers. Lines of cars on busy Nanjing Street crowd the front of the vast building, which is close to the Plaza 66 luxury shopping centre.

The current location of Jing'an Temple seems of a piece with its hectic history. Founded in 247 AD during the Three Kingdoms period, it was transferred to its present site in 1216, and destroyed by fire in 1972. In 1930, the temple was run by Abbot Khi Vehdu, a very popular gangster who was always surrounded by Russian bodyguards. The sobriety of the vast courtyard and buildings will surprise you.

The temple, rebuilt in 1984, has maintained the elegance and style of the Song dynasty. Although it has lost many treasures, it houses a pure jade statue of Sakyamuni Buddha, to which the temple is devoted. It is not uncommon to see stock traders from the neighbourhood praying and asking for prosperity in their business…

Jing'an Temple
1686, Nanjing West Road
Jing'an
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6256 6366

content.title: Lost Heaven: for Mia tribe-style shrimp

introduction.small: In this Paradise Lost, the cuisines of many southern Chinese tribes are served in soft lighting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lost Heaven: for Mia tribe-style shrimp

paragraphs.text:
If you want to surprise your guests, take them to this lost paradise, specialising in cuisine from the Yunnan province in southern China, which borders with Burma, Laos, and Vietnam. The menu offers a nice variety of dishes, as the cuisine is influenced by numerous ethnic groups. The vintage pink decor, subdued red lighting, multi-coloured pottery, and ornate artisanal chairs at Lost Heaven immediately create a warm atmosphere.

On the menu: hot and bitter shrimp in the manner of the Mia tribe, wild grain pancakes, cod with spices in banana leaf, shrimp and green bean doughnuts, spicy soup with bitter tomato, chicken steamed with wild mushrooms from the Tibetan mountains, etc. Dishes are served on beautiful covered plates. The terrace is lovely, attracting a young, party-loving clientele who go there for the drinks.

Lost Heaven
17 Yan'an East Road
Huangpu District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6330 0967

www.lostheaven.com.cn

Menu: around 130 CNY

content.title: The Langham Shanghai Xintiandi, and not just for its patio

introduction.small: The refined Langham has chosen to showcase itself in luxurious Xintiandi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Langham Shanghai Xintiandi, and not just for its patio

paragraphs.text:
The harmoniously curving facade of glass and steel overlooks Xintiandi, Shanghai's luxury shopping and restaurant district. And the concave shape of its large reception atrium, lit by a majestic chandelier, will make you want to book a room at the Langham. The hotel exudes a sense of well-being even before the entrance, from the peaceful oasis of its wide terrace with outdoor bar.

The bar staff, like that of the entire hotel, is not just highly professional, but very friendly to guests. The rooms are subtly luxurious. In beige and ochre, they are luminous, thanks to large windows that stretch from floor to ceiling.

And while you are here, have a relaxing spa treatment at the Chuan, one of the best in town.

The Langham Shanghai Xintiandi
99, Madang Road
Huangpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 2330 2288

www.langhamhotels.com/en/the-langham/shanghai/

Rooms: from 1,982 CNY

content.title: The Shanghai Museum: 5,000 years of glory

introduction.small: Between Heaven and Earth, one of the finest museums in the country presents China in all its splendour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Shanghai Museum: 5,000 years of glory

paragraphs.text:
The museum fits harmoniously into the People's Square. Its base, a beige stone tripod, supports a big circle carved in the same stone. Thus, the architect pays homage to two essential elements in Chinese tradition: the Earth, represented by a square, and Heaven, which is round. From the entrance, its transparent atrium gives the museum harmony.

The beautifully arranged collections feature the latest lighting technology, which, in the paintings gallery, illuminates the masterpieces as one approaches them and bathes them in darkness as one walks away.

This is an exceptional journey through 5,000 years of civilisation. Perhaps you have heard of the famous gallery of bronzes on the ground floor with its sublime axes, bells, and Buddhist statues. Each gallery, in fact, is full of equally stunning works. There is the meditative beauty to be found in fabulous paintings, pieces of the purest cicada-shaped jade meant to be placed in the mouth of the deceased, divine celadon jars, sandalwood cabinets from the Ming era—all will fill you with deep emotion.

Shanghai Museum
201 Renmin Avenue
Huangpu
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6372 3500

www.shanghaimuseum.net

content.title: The Yangtze Boutique Shanghai: the art de vivre of Art Decor

introduction.small: Enter this flagship hotel, the pride of Shanghai when it opened in 1934 and, for a long while, the third-largest hotel in Asia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Yangtze Boutique Shanghai: the art de vivre of Art Decor

paragraphs.text:
The beautiful white geometric facade of the Yangtze with its delightful small black balconies and rigorous foundation is just steps from People's Square, in the heart of Shanghai. Are you going up to your room? Maybe you'll want to stay awhile in the lobby.

Its burgundy carpet, tall burgundy or mauve armchairs, elegant friezes on the walls, gold-framed paintings, and piano next to the staircase all combine to create a warm atmosphere. Under the blue and green glass roof, an Art Deco gem, is the grand curved staircase. And the rooms are an extension of this warmth, combining red, ochre, and beige in a harmonious design that blends curves and straight lines.

The walls are decorated with black-and-white photos of the hotel before its renovation in 2009, when glass-walled bathrooms were incorporated into all the rooms. A very good idea.

The Yangtze Boutique Shanghai
740, Hankou Road
Huang Pu District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6080 0800

www.theyangtzehotel.com

Rooms: from 1,788 CNY

content.title: Goodfellas: mushroom risotto on the Bund

introduction.small: The ultimate seal of approval: Shanghai Italians all come here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Goodfellas: mushroom risotto on the Bund

paragraphs.text:
One of the best Italian tables in Shanghai is both friendly and chic. Italians rave about the variety and quality of the food here, as well as the choice of wines on the menu! Marco, the restaurant's Venetian maitre d', warmly welcomes guests, and the staff is tremendously attentive.

The walls are lined with black-and-white photos of Italian movie stars, and the room accommodates couples who wish to dine intimately as well as large groups who come here to feast together.

What does Marco suggest? Very crispy bruschetta, pasta with very fresh seafood, risotto with porcini mushrooms, and tiramisu. Everything is delicious. And, at the end of the meal, the restaurant offers a complimentary limoncello, just like in Italy. Book ahead because the restaurant's reasonable prices have made it a big hit in the Bund

Goodfellas
7, Yan'an Dong Lu
Shanghai

+83 (0)21 6323 2188

www.goodfellasrestaurant.net

Menu: around 300 CNY

content.title: Meet the panda at the Shanghai zoo

introduction.small: Visit one of the finest zoos in China in one of Shanghai's most forested neighbourhoods.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meet the panda at the Shanghai zoo

paragraphs.text:
Allow an entire day to fully enjoy the place, one of the largest green spaces in the city. This park zoo, former racecourse, and golf course is spread over 74 hectares. Lose yourself and safely discover many species. Considered one of the best in China with its large enclosures, the zoo is home to over 600 rare animals, including the famous giant panda with its black and white fur, the debonair tutelary animal of China, and a native of Sichuan.

A large crowd comes here every day to see one or more of the 10 pandas (a lucky number!) that live in the reserved enclosure. This highly wooded park is also home to other endangered animals, such as the South China tiger, Formosan rock monkeys, and monk cranes. In an effort to promote conservation, the zoo participates in anti bear poaching campaigns.

Shanghai Zoo
2381, Hongqiao Road
Changning District
Shanghai

+86 (0)21 6268 7775

www.shanghaizoo.cn
